security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and conversational guidelines. No executable code, no network access, no filesystem access beyond own reference files, no environment variables, no external commands. This is a documentation-only skill for scientific brainstorming methodology.

content.user_title: Generate scientific hypotheses and research ideas
content.value_statement: Scientists often face creative blocks when developing novel research directions. This skill provides structured brainstorming techniques and interdisciplinary thinking strategies to generate hypotheses, explore connections across fields, and develop innovative methodologies.
actual_capabilities: Guide scientific ideation through structured 5-phase workflow
Apply 9+ brainstorming frameworks including SCAMPER and TRIZ
Generate cross-domain analogies and interdisciplinary connections
Challenge assumptions and identify unexplored research angles
Synthesize ideas into concrete research directions and next steps
Adapt techniques when scientists face creative blocks
limitations: Does not access external databases or literature searches
Does not validate scientific claims or verify existing research
Cannot access user files or project codebases
Provides guidance only; does not execute experiments

use_cases.title: Explore new research directions
use_cases.description: Graduate students and professors use this skill to overcome creative blocks and discover novel hypotheses for papers and grants.

use_cases.title: Develop innovative solutions
use_cases.description: R&D teams apply cross-domain thinking to solve product development challenges using established creativity frameworks.

use_cases.title: Refine thesis questions
use_cases.description: PhD candidates brainstorm methodology approaches and identify gaps in existing literature with structured guidance.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Start
prompt_templates.prompt: I am working on [describe research area]. Help me generate 5 novel hypotheses by applying cross-domain analogies from other fields.

prompt_templates.title: Challenge Assumptions
prompt_templates.prompt: My current research assumes [state assumption]. Challenge this assumption and propose 3 alternative frameworks that could explain the phenomenon.

prompt_templates.title: Apply Framework
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the SCAMPER framework to systematically explore improvements to my current methodology for [describe method]. Provide specific scientific applications.

prompt_templates.title: Synthesize Directions
prompt_templates.prompt: We have brainstormed several ideas for [research problem]. Help me identify the most promising direction and outline concrete next steps including initial experiments.

output_examples.input: I am studying antibiotic resistance in bacterial populations. Help me generate novel hypotheses.
output: Cross-domain hypothesis: Apply network theory from social sciences to model resistance gene transfer as information diffusion patterns
Scale-shifting approach: Consider resistance at the microbiome ecosystem level rather than individual bacterial cells
Assumption reversal: What if antibiotics themselves trigger resistance mechanisms rather than selecting for pre-existing variants?

best_practices: Begin by clearly articulating your research context, constraints, and what obstacles you face
Use specific frameworks like SCAMPER or Six Thinking Hats when standard brainstorming stalls
Move from divergent thinking to focused synthesis before ending each session
anti_patterns: Expecting complete solutions without providing research context or constraints
Using the skill for literature searches instead of ideation and hypothesis generation
Skipping the understanding phase and jumping directly to idea generation

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code for research ideation conversations.

faq.question: What brainstorming frameworks are included?
faq.answer: Nine frameworks: SCAMPER, Six Thinking Hats, Morphological Analysis, TRIZ, Biomimicry, Provocation, Random Input, Reverse Assumptions, and Future Backwards.

faq.question: How does this integrate with my research workflow?
faq.answer: Use it early in your process to generate hypotheses and explore directions. It complements but does not replace literature review and experimentation.

faq.question: Is my research data safe?
faq.answer: This prompt-only skill does not access files, databases, or external systems. Conversations remain private to your AI session.

faq.question: What if I get stuck during brainstorming?
faq.answer: The skill includes adaptive techniques for when ideas run dry, including problem reframing, changing perspectives, and introducing provocations.

faq.question: How is this different from general brainstorming tools?
faq.answer: This skill is designed specifically for scientific contexts with domain-aware techniques for hypothesis generation, methodology development, and research gap identification.
